title: Booking.com parent takes stake in Serko
text:
Serko chief executive Darrin Grafton said the agreement would fuel the company's growth outside of its core market of Australia and New Zealand.

"It is fantastic to partner with Booking.com, the world leader in online travel and related services,'' Mr Grafton said.

Mr Grafton co-founded Serko with Bob Shaw in 2007 and then listed it on the NZ Stock Exchange in 2014.

Serko shares showed robust growth of 70 per cent in the first eight months of 2019, from $2.49 in early January to $4.33 on September 4. But they slid back substantially over the next few weeks to close at $2.96 on Wednesday.

Serko announced on Thursday that Booking Holdings, which is listed on the NASDAQ exchange in the United States, would end up with a shareholding of about 4.7 per cent in the company as a cornerstone investor.

The overall capital raising consists of a primary placement of NZ$40 million of new shares, along with a secondary sale of shares of NZ$16 million by Mr Grafton, chairman Simon Botherway and some other Serko employees.

A share purchase plan is being offered to shareholders to raise up to NZ$5 million.

Mr Grafton's selldown represents about 13 per cent of his current holding in the company.

The placement is being underwritten by New Zealand stockbroker Deutsche Craigs Ltd.

Ripsy Bandourian, the vice-president of partnerships at Booking.com, said the group had similar views about making business travel ''frictionless'' for both travellers and travel managers.

Serko has already been investing heavily in an expansion in the United States after buying US expense management business InterplX last year.
description: The US$83 billion online travel giant which owns Booking.com and agoda.com is the biggest investor in a capital raising by dual-listed Serko.
